Rationale

A  loan  is  proposed  for  the  Public  Service  Program  (PSP),  to
support  policy  and  institutional  changes  to  strengthen  the  public
service in PNG.

PNG faces formidable development challenges. The Government
has  formulated  and  has  begun  implementing  a  wide-ranging
structural  reform  program  (SRP),  embracing  public  service  and
economic reforms.

The quality of public sector management in PNG has deteriorated
over  the  past  decade.  As  is  strongly  emphasized  by  the
Government,  poor  governance  is  the  root  cause.  The  public
sector’s  capacity  for  designing  and  implementing  sound  policies
and to manage its responsibilities has been eroded.

A  broad  consensus  has  arisen  that  the  situation  must  be
reversed.  The  Government  has  committed  itself  to  a  program  of
reform  to  restore  the  integrity  of  the  public  service.  Beginning  in
2000,  the  Government  has  drawn  up  a  comprehensive  plan  of
action for public sector reform, and implementation is under way.

Improving performance in the public sector is a main pillar in the
Government’s  SRP,  alongside  concurrent  measures  to  sustain
macroeconomic  stability  and  remove  barriers  to  private  sector
development. For the SRP to succeed, it will be important for the
Government  to  demonstrate  improvements  in  services  to  the
general  public,  particularly  front-line  services  to  urban  and  rural
poor  communities.  The  actions  under  the  PSP  are  essential  for
achieving the needed reorientation of the public service.

The PSP will support, as part of the broader reform agenda of the
Government,  policy  reform  measures  in  four  areas:  (i) building  a
performance-oriented  public  service,  (ii)  reorienting  personnel
management  systems  and  processes,  (iii)  strengthening  probity
and  oversight  agencies,  and  (iv)  improving  delivery  of  major

II. 

INTRODUCTION

From the beginning of 1998, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been in dialogue
2.
with  the  PNG  Government  concerning  its  request  for  assistance  to  improve  public  sector
performance in PNG. However, the developing macroeconomic crisis slowed progress. In July
1999,  a  new  government  came  to  power,  providing  an  opportunity  for  ADB  and  the  other
development agencies involved in PNG to assist the Government to reform the economy and to
reorient  the  public  sector.  In  1999,  the  Government  formulated  its  structural  reform  program
(SRP).  At  the  November  1999  Consultative  Group  Meeting,  the  Government  reiterated  its
intention to seek assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, as
well as from ADB and other agencies. The Government finalized agreements with IMF in April
2000 and with the World Bank in June 2000; these agreements led to ancillary agreements for
assistance with, notably, Australia, the European Union, and Japan. The IMF and World Bank
programs  are  targeted  at  addressing  fiscal  and  balance-of-payments  issues,  financial  sector
reform,  and  privatization  of  state-owned  enterprises.  The  Government  requested  ADB
assistance for public sector reform. A technical assistance (TA) was approved in October 1999
for preparing a governance and public sector reform program.1 The budgets for 2000 and 2001,
prepared with IMF and World Bank assistance, identified funding gaps for structural adjustment
expenditures.  The  Government  has  requested  ADB  financing  through  a  policy-based  program
loan for the PSP, as a part of its overall SRP.

3.
A fact-finding mission was fielded during 13 February-1 March 2001, a follow-up mission
during 16-28 July 2001, and an appraisal mission during 3-22 September 2001.2 This report is
based  on  the  findings  of  the  missions  and  consultations  with  key  officials  in  Government  and
representatives of aid agencies. The program framework is in Appendix 1. The national policy
agenda  and  reform  priorities  of  the  Government  are  summarized  in  the  development  policy
letter from the Prime Minister (Appendix 2), which includes the policy matrix for the ADB loan,
given in Appendix 3.

III. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT

A. 

Development Objectives, Strategy, and Plans

4.
The primary development challenge in PNG is poverty alleviation. Most of the people of
PNG  are  poor  by  regional  and  international  standards.  The  human  development  index  (HDI)
score  for  1998  of  0.542  placed  PNG  in  133rd  position  on  a  list  of  174  developing  countries.
Among  Pacific  island  countries,  PNG  was  last  on  the  HDI  scale.  In  1996,  31  percent  of  the
population lived below the international poverty line of $1 per capita per day; 37 percent were
below the country-specific poverty line in that same year. Around 17 percent of the population
could not meet the basic requirement of 2,200 calories per day per adult equivalent, even if they

5.
Income distribution is also a concern. The richest 10 percent of the population account
for  36  percent  of  consumption,  while  the  poorest  50  percent  account  for  only  20  percent.
Growth, led by a capital-intensive minerals sector, has supported increasing consumption by an
urban  elite.  Accordingly,  the  vast  majority  of  the  poor  (93.5  percent)  live  in  rural  areas.  The
urbanized National Capital District has a poverty rate of 25.8 percent, and accounts for just 3.8
percent of the poor.

6.
Poverty  also  has  a  gender  dimension.  Across  nearly  all  indicators,  women  fare  worse
than men. Indeed, PNG is one of the few countries in the world where women have a lower life
expectancy than men. Women are responsible for a disproportionately large amount of work in
the rural sector, but are generally under represented in senior positions in the public and private
sectors.

However, the data point to promising approaches for alleviating poverty. In about three-
7.
quarters of poor households, there has been little, if any, human capital investment. Almost 52
percent  of  the  poor  live  in  households  whose  head  never  attended  school.  Likewise,  girls'
enrollment  rates  are  significantly  influenced  by  the  educational  level  of  adult  females  in  the
household. The incidence of poverty is also linked to the ability to earn cash to pay for nonfood
items  (such  as  school  fees)  and  to  permit  savings  for  times  of  economic  difficulty.  Where
household  heads  earn  cash  income  from  wage  employment  or  a  business,  poverty  rates  are
much  lower.  Poverty  alleviation  therefore  requires  improved  access  to  services,  such  as
transport, education, and health, particularly in rural areas.

8.
In  PNG,  the  formal  safety  net  is  provided  by  provident  funds;  these  systems  are
therefore  limited  to  wage  earners.  Provident  funds  in  PNG  have  performed  poorly  and  are
currently  the  focus  of  reform  efforts.  Informal  social  safety  nets  (the wantok systems)  provide
income transfers, labor exchange, and sharing of gardening and child care to those within the
same clan or tribe. However, these systems are less effective in communities with high poverty
rates, where people therefore have less of a surplus to share with others.

9.
In recent years, PNG's ability to address rising poverty has been constrained mainly by
economic  policy  shortcomings  and  political  instability.  The  current  Government  has  moved
decisively to address these fundamental constraints.

10.
On  the  political  side,  the  Government  is  taking  measures  to  improve  stability.  In  late
2000, the Parliament passed a bill to strengthen the role of political parties, and to reduce the
potential for switching,  thus reducing the political horsetrading that has long been a feature  of
PNG. Government has also endorsed a fundamental change in the electoral system, from the
present  first-past-the-post  system  to  a  system  of  limited  preferential  voting,  which  will  help
ensure that members of parliament have a wider constituency.

The Government recognizes that the root cause of PNG’s weak economic performance
11.
is  poor  governance,  characterized  by  a  decline  in  public  institutions’  performance,  poor
transparency  of  policy  making,  and  political  interference  in  policy  implementation.  These
weaknesses are being addressed through a wide-ranging SRP.

12.
The Government’s first priority has been to minimize fiscal deficits in order to reduce the
rate of increase of indebtedness and to help restore stability and integrity to the economy and

 3

banking system by delivering a reasonably balanced budget. The Government’s commitment to
the SRP is evident from the strict fiscal constraints it has adopted. The 2000 and 2001 budgets
have  essentially  been  balanced,  apart  from  repayment  of  arrears  and  a  modest  provision  for
structural  reforms.  Within  the  constrained  overall  expenditure  ceiling,  the  Government  has
prioritized  expenditure  on  health,  education,  peace  and  order,  agriculture,  and  infrastructure
maintenance—no  other  sectors  have  received  increased  allocations.  No  new  external
commercial  borrowing  is  envisaged.  Central  bank  financing  of  the  budget  also  has  been
eliminated.  Under  a  new  central  banking  act  (March  2000),  the  central  bank’s  role  was
redefined, ensuring its independence and limiting its financing of government activities to short-
term liquidity management. The resulting imposition of harder fiscal discipline constitutes what
will be a long lasting improvement in governance.

PNG has had a substantial overhang of short-term domestic debt, with the resulting high
13.
debt service constraining public spending on public services. The Government has been retiring
this domestic debt as quickly as possible, in part by improving its management of net assets. As
a  central  plank  of  its  program,  the  Government  also  has  been  converting  domestic  short-term
debt  into  long-term  concessional  foreign  debt,  thereby  freeing  up  budget  resources  and
reducing the pressure on domestic credit to the private sector. The Government has also been
conducting  a  successful  program  of  clearing  up  arrears,  and  ensuring  that  new  arrears  are
avoided  (the  temporary  cash  flow  difficulties  in  2001  have  resulted  in  some  build-up  again  of
arrears).

14.
To  conclude,  the  framework  for  the  programs,  including  the  fiscal  sector  management
initiative, must be viewed against the Government's comprehensive SRP (para. 2), which aims
to (i) promote good governance; (ii) sustain macroeconomic stability; (iii) improve public sector
performance in the core areas through privatization, reduce the involvement of the public sector
where  its  performance  has  been  poor  and  where  the  private  sector  can  improve  service
delivery; and (iv) remove barriers to investment and economic development.

B. 

Recent Economic Performance and Prospects

15.
In  1995,  following  a  balance-of-payments  crisis,  the  Government  embarked  on  a
comprehensive structural adjustment program. Until mid-1997, the tightening of macroeconomic
policies  achieved  some  success  in  bringing  down  inflation,  rebuilding  foreign  exchange
reserves, and fostering a recovery of output. However, there was little success in achieving the
broad structural reform agenda. Beginning in late 1997, the economy was battered by a series
of adverse exogenous shocks, including a prolonged drought that affected mining output as well
as agricultural production, and the regional financial crisis, which caused steep declines in the
prices of, and demand for, PNG’s principal export commodities. The macroeconomic effects of
these  shocks  were  exacerbated  by  weak  monetary  policy  and  deteriorating  budget
management.  The  deterioration  of  governance,  marked  by  increasing  political  interference  in
implementation of public policy, further undermined private sector confidence. The situation was
compounded by a breakdown in relations with the external development partners.

A broader legacy of the performance through the 1990s is a stagnating standard of living
16.
and  social  indicators  for  the  population.  Based  on  1996  poverty  data,  over  37  percent  of  the
population  falls  below  the  poverty  line.  The  situation  of  the  poorest  quartile  has  not  improved
since  1984,  and  developments  since  1996  have  worsened  the  disparities.  Low  educational
achievements, inadequate delivery of basic services, especially in rural areas, and inadequate
infrastructure and institutional support exacerbate the situation. The results of the 2000 census

 4

indicate that the population has been growing more rapidly than expected, with the likely result
that per capita incomes have been overestimated.

17.
A new government took office in July 1999 with a mandate to stabilize macroeconomic
conditions, improve the governance of public institutions, and restore relations with international
financial institutions and bilateral partners. The Government launched a reform program aimed
at stabilizing the economy and creating the conditions for growth led by the private sector. The
Government  took  measures  to  rein  in  the  growing  fiscal  deficit  and  tightened  monetary  policy
during  the  second  half  of  1999.  The  Government  adopted  an  adjustment  program  focused  on
sound fiscal management and reforms to improve the governance, transparency, and efficiency
of the public sector. The Government was successful in reestablishing dialogue and agreement
with the international community, with immediate results. Aided by an $80 million bridging loan
from  the  Australian  government  and  the  release  of  a  $25  million  program  loan  tranche  from
ADB,3  together  with  a  turnaround  of  some  commodity  prices,  the  central  bank  was  able  to
recoup  a  significant  amount  of  reserves  by  early  2000.  The  Government  also  reached
agreements on support from IMF in March 2000 and with the World Bank in June 2000, together
with linked financial packages from Australia, Japan, and other sources.4

18.
Real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  declined  by  1.8  percent  in  2000,  although  the
external  current  account  surplus  widened  and  inflation  declined.  Mineral  production  was
depressed  by  the  start  of  a  secular  decline  in  oil  production  due  to  depletion  of  oil  reserves.
Nonmineral  output  contracted,  in  part  due  to  fiscal  restraint  and  tight  credit  conditions.  The
overall  Government  deficit  was  reduced  substantially  to  1.3  percent  of  GDP  (below  targets),
largely  because  of  improved  mineral  tax  revenue.  However,  there  were  delays  in  fulfilling  IMF
and World Bank target conditions. A shortfall in external financing led the Government to resort
to domestic financing. Nevertheless, for the year as a whole, net domestic financing declined as
a share of GDP. Although the kina depreciated by 13.7 percent against the United States dollar
by year end, the rate of inflation declined to 10 percent by year end (compared to the target of 5
percent).

19.
Economic  conditions  continued  to  be  difficult  in  the  first  half  of  2001.  The  economy
remains stagnant, with oil output and nonmineral activity declining. Uncertainties in the relations
with  multilateral  institutions  in  the  early  part  of  the  year,  and  unrest  in  the  military  in  March,
contributed to pressures on the kina. Market interest rates remained high. Delays in the receipt
of external financing led to fiscal pressures and a temporary breach of the limit on central bank
lending  to  the  Government.  The  pressures  eased  somewhat  as  the  authorities  secured  early
release  of  the  second  tranche  of  a  budgetary  support  loan  from  Australia  (tied  to  satisfactory
assessment  of  progress  by  IMF)  and  the  release  of  a  World  Bank  loan  tranche  in  July  2001.
Nevertheless the situation remains tight.

inadequate  development
management. Corruption, political patronage, and weak public administration have undermined
the professional ethos of the public service. These factors are major constraints to the efforts to
alleviate poverty in PNG. The extent of poverty is a direct consequence of sustained low levels
of  investment  and  poor  quality  of  services  in  rural  areas,  particularly  in  such  key  sectors  as
agriculture, education, and health. Public services have deteriorated steadily over the past two
decades  and  have  reached  unacceptably  low  levels.  In  a  1996  survey,  the  PNG  population
expressed  its  collective  dissatisfaction.  The  poorest  quartile  of  the  population  was  the  most
dissatisfied  with  the  state  of  government  services.  Lowest  performance  ratings  were  given  to
services in the Highlands and Momase/North Coast Regions where the majority of the poor live.

21.
The Government acknowledges the validity of this public perception. Key policy makers
accept that the core functions of the public sector have not been fulfilled efficiently or effectively
and  that  this  failure  of  past  governments  has  adversely  affected  the  poor  most  of  all.  This
recognition has led the Government to feature good governance and public service performance
improvement as key objectives of its reform program. Clearly, efforts at sound macroeconomic
management and structural adjustment have little meaning unless they enhance public services
and  result  in  higher  living  standards  for  the  population.  The  following  sections  describes  the
features  of  the  Government's  SRP  and  the  major  policy  actions  that  have  been  planned  or
completed under the SRP.

B. 

Government Expenditure and Economic Management

22.
The Government has transformed economic management. The exchange rate, interest
rates,  and  liquidity  management  are  now  market  based.  The  Government  has  devoted
considerable  attention  to  strengthening  fiscal  management,  improving  transparency,  and
reestablishing  proper  procedures.  Government  departments  are  reporting  all  spending
commitments, with development budget warrants integrated with the recurrent budget warrants.
Monthly cash flow reports are produced. Expenditure controls have been enhanced and the use
of  trust  accounts  essentially  stopped.  Substantial  arrears  incurred  by  previous  governments
have been cleared during 1999 and 2000.

23.
The Government is fully committed to strengthening the policy framework of government
expenditure.  The  Government  has  explicitly  based  its  national  budgets  on  its  development
objectives,  with  the  development  policy  framework  central  in  budget  formulation.  More
fundamentally,  the  Government  is  moving  toward  a  multi-year  approach  to  expenditure
planning. As part of the process, the tools of financial management are being strengthened, with
external assistance, including from ADB.5

24.
In 1999, the Government started a review of the tax system to strengthen the fiscal base
(with  ADB  TA  for  mining  and  hydrocarbons  taxes6).  The  recommendations  were  introduced  in
the  2001  budget.  The  purpose  was  to  ensure  that  PNG’s  personal  and  corporate  taxes  were

31.
The first dimension involves measures to strengthen the performance orientation of the
public service. As an initial step, departments are required to define their outputs and to prepare
corporate plans and budgets with these objectives and outputs in mind. Public access to these

define departmental outputs and report on accomplishments may, in the early stages, be off the
mark  or  less  than  satisfactory.  However,  the  exercise  is  expected  to  raise  awareness  of  the

establishing  cost-effective  measures  for  monitoring  and  measuring  performance,  and  to
providing  appropriate  incentives,  through  the  budget  process,  to  reward  higher  performing
departments.  While  the  focus  will  be  on  national-level  departments  initially,  the  process  will
need eventually to cover provincial governments as well.

32.
The  second  dimension  involves  policy  actions  to  reorient  personnel  management
systems and to ensure that such systems and processes are fair, transparent, merit based, and
insulated  from  arbitrary  action  of  politicians.  Personnel  management  processes  are  being
reviewed and revised. A key step is the integration of human resource management and payroll
systems to ensure accurate information, permit national human resource planning, and reduce
waste (by eliminating overpayments of salaries and benefits); the payroll and human resource
management  system  will  be  fully  consistent  with  the  financial  management  systems  being
concurrently developed. Further enhancements, beyond the PSP, will include capacity building
at  all  levels of the public  service to enable smooth implementation of processes for personnel
management, particularly at provincial and local government levels.

departments  of  national  planning  and  monitoring,  justice  and  attorney  general,  and  provincial
and local level government.

deliverers  to  improve  service  quality.  Each  pilot  province  will  establish  service  quality
improvement  teams  in  the  provincial  administrations.  These  teams  will  concentrate  on  priority
services, coaching district and provincial teams in improving their productivity. Award programs
will be established to recognize and reward high performing staff and service delivery units.

D. 

Social and Environmental Issues

1.

Social Impact

59.
The poverty impact of the PSP is discussed in Appendix 4. In summary, implementation
of  the  PSP  and  the  funding  support  provided  by  the  PSP  loan  will  result  in  improved  public
service  delivery.  Higher  and  more  focused  public  spending  will  provide  greater  access  to  key
public services by the poor in four provinces. Hence, the major positive impact on the poor of
the PSP is increased access to basic public services.

In  addition,  there  will  be  indirect  positive  impact  through  the  labor  market,  by  enabling
60.
more  private  sector  activity.  This  in  turn  will  increase  the  chances  of  higher  economic  growth
and employment creation. The increased demand is likely to benefit those in formal employment
primarily, and may generate some employment in the informal sector.

61.
The  loan  will  support  the  Government's  efforts  to  maintain  a  stable  macroeconomic
environment while implementing the SRP. It will cover short- and medium-term adjustment costs
during 2001-2003. It will augment foreign reserves and thus alleviate any speculative pressure
on the currency that could lead to depreciation and higher prices. On the other hand, the easing
of the constraint on public expenditure will increase aggregate demand, which will increase the
general  price  level.  The  net  effect  cannot  be  predicted,  but  is  unlikely  to  have  a  significant
immediate impact on poverty. In the medium to long run, the structural adjustments are likely to
result  in  improved  productivity  and  a  positive  supply  response  with  a  beneficial  impact  on
poverty.

62.
The  PSP  loan  may  increase  the  likelihood  of  a  nominal  appreciation  of  the  currency,
which  could  have  a  negative  effect  on  the  poor  insofar  as  they  are  net  producers  of  traded
goods and net consumers of nontraded goods. Against this, the PSP underpins the provision of
basic  services  at  zero  or  nominal  charges,  thus  benefiting  the  poor.  The  net  effect  of  relative
price shifts is difficult to predict, but is in any case substantially overshadowed by the positive
impact on the availability of public goods and services with the PSP.

63.
The impact on transfers through direct Government programs is largely covered by the
poverty impact assessment matrix category of access of the poor to nonmarketed public goods
and  services.  In  addition,  however,  the  PSP  will  enhance  the  capacity  to  formulate  and
implement public works programs in which the poor are given work.

 14

Accordingly, the PSP will have a significant positive impact on the poor because of the
64.
positive  effect  of  basic  public  services.  The  public  service  will  become  performance  oriented,
and public expenditure on the services essential to poverty alleviation will increase. The direct
positive  effect  will  be  reinforced  by  the  indirect  positive  effects  of  a  better  governance
environment and improved public administration on economic growth.

65.
The  CACC  will  retain  the  responsibility  for  overall  coordination  of  the  PSP,  while  the
PSRMU established by the NEC will be responsible for coordination on a daily basis. General
monitoring  of  PSP  implementation  will  be  undertaken  by  ADB  in  partnership  with  the
Government  on  a  regular  basis—formal  joint  reviews  by  ADB  and  PSRMU  will  be  undertaken
every six months, supplementing PSRMU reports every three months. For assessing the PSP’s
impact on poverty, key performance indicators will be the share of public expenditure allocated
to  basic  service  provision  in  rural  areas  (details  of  this  allocation  are  available  for  the  health
sector  and  are  being  developed  for  education),  and  the  extent  of  client  satisfaction  with
provincial service delivery as revealed in surveys. A system of client satisfaction surveys will be
established  under  the  program,  to  be  contracted  out  to  qualified  commercial  organizations.
Results of the latter are to be documented in the reports of line ministries to CACC. Ultimately,
progress  in  reducing  poverty  may  be  evaluated  through  regular  poverty  analyses  based  on
comparable household survey data.

2.

Environmental Issues

66.
The  PSP  is  classified  as  Category  C  by  ADB’s  environmental  classification  system.  Its
environmental  impact  is  expected  to  be  minimal.  The  PSP  does  not  deal  directly  with
environmental concerns. Other funding agencies, particularly AusAID and the World Bank, are
providing  assistance  and  supporting  reforms  to  deal  with  resource  and  environmental
management  issues,  notably  in  the  forestry  sector,  where  there  remain  significant  issues.
However,  the  corruption-reducing  effects  of  the  PSP  should  be  of  particular  benefit  in  the
forestry sector.

A. 

Amount of Loan and Source of Funds

VI. 

THE PROPOSED LOAN

67.
It is proposed that ADB provide from its ordinary capital resources a loan of $70 million
to support the PSP, as part of the Government’s SRP. The amount of the loan is based on the
cost  of  the  ongoing  structural  adjustment,  including  direct  costs  of  the  PSP,  and  reflects  the
importance  and  urgency  of  the  reforms,  the  state  of  the  public  finances  in  PNG,  and  the
availability  of  funding  for  the  Government’s  overall  program.  The  loan  and  its  proposed  use
have been included in the Government’s agreement with IMF. The loan funds will be released in
two  tranches.  The  first  tranche  of  $35  million  will  be  made  available  when  the  loan  becomes
effective; the net amount disbursed will reflect amounts due to ADB, including the front-end fee
on the loan and recovery of project preparatory TA costs. The second tranche of $35 million will
be made available when all conditions for release of the second tranche have been fulfilled, as
specified  in  the  policy  matrix.  This  is  targeted  for  September  2002;  however,  should  the
conditions be satisfied earlier, then the second tranche may be released earlier.

B. 

Interest, Maturity, and Disbursement Period

68.
The loan will have a maturity of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; an interest
rate  determined  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  lending  facility  based  on  the  London  interbank
offer  rate  (LIBOR);  a  commitment  charge  of  0.75  percent  per  annum;  a  front-end  fee  of

 15

1.0 percent  (which  will  be  capitalized  in  the  loan  and  deducted  from  the  first  tranche);
conversion  options  that  may  be  exercised  in  accordance  with  the  terms  of  the  draft  Loan
Agreement,  the  Loan  Regulation,  and  ADB’s  Conversion  Guidelines;  and  other  terms  and
conditions set forth in the draft Loan Agreement. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the
reasons for PNG’s decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis of
these terms and conditions, and (ii) assurance that these choices were PNG's own independent
decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any  communication  or  advice  of  ADB.  The  loan  is
expected to be disbursed over a 10-month period, with PSP implementation continuing until the
end of 2003.

C. 

Implementation Arrangements

To  ensure  appropriate,  high-level,  and  effective  coordination  during  implementation  of
69.
the PSP, the CACC will be tasked with overall coordination, in consultation with the heads of the
concerned agencies. The Government has established a secretariat to support CACC activities
and  will  provide  the  secretariat  with  necessary  staff  and  resources,  acceptable  to  ADB,
throughout PSP implementation. The Department of Treasury will be the Executing Agency for
the PSP (with primary responsibility for the loan and loan funds). PMNEC will be responsible for
the PSP and its overall implementation. Key agencies to be involved in PSP implementation will
be DPM, the Department of Finance, and the Department of National Planning and Monitoring.
The  implementation  will  be  coordinated  on  a  day-to-day  basis  by  the  PSRMU  and  will  be
undertaken by all concerned agencies. External assistance for implementation will be provided
under the PSP.

D. 

Disbursement and Procurement

70.
The  proceeds  of  the  loan  will  be  disbursed  against  a  broad  range  of  imports  with  the
counterpart funds generated to be used to support the costs of PSP implementation and related
adjustment  costs.  The  proceeds  of  the  loan  will  be  used  only  to  finance  the  foreign  exchange
costs  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries  except  the  ineligible  items
(Appendix 5) and imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The Government
will submit with each withdrawal request a certification that the value of total net eligible imports
is  expected  to  be  equal  to  or  greater  than  the  amount  of  the  ADB  projected  disbursements
under the PSP loan in a given period, and that the required withdrawal will be used to finance
eligible  items  procured  in  accordance  with  the  loan  agreement  provisions.  ADB  will  have  the
right  to  audit  the  use  of  the  loan  proceeds  and  to  verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Government's
certification. Procurement using loan funds will be based on normal commercial practice by the
private sector, except that goods commonly traded on international commodity markets will be
procured in accordance with procedures appropriate to the trade. ADB will continue to ensure
that  standard  public  and  private  procurement  procedures  used  in  PNG  are  adequate  in
competition and efficiency.

E. 

Counterpart Funds

Counterpart funds generated from the proceeds of the PSP will be used to finance local
71.
counterpart costs related to the implementation of the PSP and the SRP during 2001–2003. An
indicative  allocation  of  use  of  the  funds  has  been  agreed.  The  Government  will  ensure  that
sufficient counterpart funds are made available to meet the costs associated with implementing
the  PSP.  The  PSP  funds  will  enable  the  Government  to  continue  its  retrenchment  program
(initially  $13  million)  including  the  costs  of  repatriation,  begin  implementing  the  service
improvement  plans  and  departmental  functional  review  recommendations  ($8 million),  and
begin  implementing  the  new  payroll  and  human  resource  management  system  ($4 million).  It

 16

will  also  help  finance  the  Government’s  ongoing  program  of  privatization  and  regulatory  and
competition reviews ($12 million), and other structural reform activities ($3 million). Any amounts
not  needed  for  these  direct  structural  adjustment  costs  will  be  used,  as  agreed  by  the
Government  and  ADB,  to  enable  the  Government  to  continue  its  program  of  retiring  the  most
expensive  (mostly  domestic)  public  debt  and  arrears.  This  program  of  expenditures  is  fully
consistent with the agreed IMF and World Bank programs.

F. 

Monitoring and Tranching

72.
ADB will carry out periodic reviews of progress in implementing the PSP. Formal reviews
will be undertaken jointly by ADB and the PSRMU (with CACC supervision) every six months.
The  Government  will  keep  ADB  informed  of  the  outcome  of  policy  discussions  that  are  with
other multilateral and bilateral aid agencies and that have implications for implementation of the
SRP.  The  representatives  of  the  Government,  ADB,  and  other  major  funding  agencies  for  the
SRP  will  meet  at  least  every  six  months  to  review  implementation  of  the  overall  SRP  and  the
PSP.  The  meetings  will  continue  after  the  closing  of  the  loan  and  will  cover  at  least  the  PSP
period  to  the  end  of  2003.  A  key  focus  of  monitoring  will  be  performance  on  the  broad  policy
reforms;  external  assistance  is  to  be  made  available  as  required,  both  under  the  PSP  and  in
separate initiatives.

In  addition  to  quarterly  progress  reports  on  PSP  performance  (to  be  prepared  by  the
73.
PSRMU), the Government will submit a program completion report to ADB within three months
of  the  loan  closing  date.  This  report  will  evaluate  the  implementation  of  the  policy  reform
measures under the PSP, their impact on the economy, lessons learned during the PSP period,
and further reforms and assistance required in the medium term.

74.
The  loan  funds  will  be  released  in  two  tranches  of  equal  size.  The  tranche  release
conditions are contained in the policy matrix (Appendix 3). The first tranche ($35 million), from
which  the  loan  front-end  fee  and  project  preparatory  TA  costs  will  be  deducted,  will  be  made
available after loan effectiveness (expected December 2001). The second tranche ($35 million)
will  be  disbursed  upon  compliance  with  second  tranche  conditions.  The  second  release  is
targeted for September 2002. However, at Government request, the release could be advanced,
if release conditions have been satisfied.

VII. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS

A. 

Benefits

75.
The  PSP  will  help  the  Government's  efforts  to  place  the  economy  on  a  sound  and
sustainable  path  and  to  begin  to  establish  an  effective  and  efficient  public  service,  capable  of
delivering  basic  services.  The  PSP  will  help  begin  to  improve  the  effectiveness  of  the  public
service  by  introducing  a  performance  orientation  and  accountability  mechanisms,  and  by
helping to streamline procedures. The PSP will help to achieve fiscal balance by trimming the
size  of  the  public  service,  including  measures  to  mitigate  harmful  impacts  by  financing  the
compensation packages for retrenched public servants. Reduction in expensive public debt will
reduce  debt  servicing.  The  PSP  will  help  revitalize  the  operations  of  the  public  service  by
reforming personnel management, and introducing stronger and more effective human resource
development  mechanisms.  The  PSP  will  also  be  instrumental  in  assisting  the  Government  to
restore the integrity of public institutions.

 B. 

Poverty Impact

17

76.
Implementation of the PSP and the funding support provided by the PSP loan will ensure
improved public service delivery. In particular, access by the poor in four provinces to key public
services  will  increase  as  a  result  of  more  focused  public  spending.  Hence,  the  major  positive
impact on the poor will be increased access to basic public services.

77.
In  addition,  the  PSP  will  have  some  indirect  positive  effects  through  the  labor  market.
With  public  service  and  governance  reforms,  the  private  sector  will  be  able  to  increase  its
activity.  This  in  turn  will  help  accelerate  economic  growth  and  consequently  contribute  to
employment creation. Public spending will then increase, and will increase the demand for labor
indirectly. The increased demand is likely to primarily benefit people in formal employment, and
may generate employment for people in the informal sector.

78.
In regard to relative price  movements, the provision of the PSP loan may increase the
likelihood of a nominal appreciation of the currency, which could have a negative effect on the
poor who are net producers of traded goods and net consumers of nontraded goods. However,
the PSP loan will support the provision of publicly-supplied services at zero or nominal charges,
thus benefiting the poor. The net effect of relative price shifts is difficult to predict, but will in any
case  be  substantially  overshadowed  by  the  positive  impact  on  the  availability  of  public  goods
and services under the PSP. In addition, the PSP will encourage a greater capacity to formulate
and implement public works programs that provide job opportunities for the poor.

79.
In sum, the PSP will have a significant positive impact on the poor because of a direct
positive  effect  on  the  provision  of  basic  public  services.  The  public  services  will  improve  as
management  focuses  on  performance  and  public  expenditure  on  the  services  essential  to
poverty  alleviation  is  increased.  The  direct  positive  effect  will  be  reinforced  by  the  indirect
positive  effects  of  a  better  governance  environment  and  improved  public  administration  on
economic growth.

C. 

Risks

A  major  risk  relates  to  the  adequacy  of  agency  capacity  and  human  and  budget
80.
resources.  Improving  this  capacity  is  the  long-term  goal  of  the  reform  process.  The  risk  has
been mitigated by specifically targeting PSP activities to begin the necessarily long process of
strengthening public sector management and achievement. Consultants will be used to help in
particular reform tasks where Government capacities are insufficient.

81.
Another  risk  to  the  successful  implementation  of  the  PSP  is  that  adversely  affected
groups may seek to undermine the content and the timing of the reforms. Such risks have been
mitigated  by  the  strong  commitment  of  senior  officials  to  continue  with  the  reforms.  The  most
immediately affected are those being retrenched, whose potential resistance is to be mitigated
by appropriate compensation.

There  are  also  risks  relating  to  the  sustainability  of  the  measures.  These  have  been
82.
minimized by restricting the recurrent implications of the reform measures as much as possible,
and  by  focusing  the  PSP  on  priority  restructuring  needs.  The  loan  will  not  be  used  to  finance
existing recurrent budget requirements.

A.

Introduction

Fighting Poverty in Asia and the Pacific: The Poverty Reduction Strategy of the Asian
1. 
Development Bank1 identifies good governance, social development, and sustainable economic
growth  as  the  three  pillars  of  an  effective  poverty  reduction  strategy.  In  Papua  New  Guinea
(PNG)  during  the  1990s,  these  pillars  were  weakened.  The  governance  environment
deteriorated significantly; there was little, if any, progress as measured by social development
indicators; and economic growth slowed down as the effects of external economic shocks were
compounded  by  macroeconomic  mismanagement.    Over  37  percent  of  the  population  was
below the national poverty line in 1996.

2. 
The Government that won office in July 1999 formulated the Structural Reform Program
(SRP) 2000 with the key objectives of promoting good governance, sustaining macroeconomic
stability,  improving  public  sector  performance,  and  removing  barriers  to  investment  and
economic development.  The proposed Public Service Program (PSP) will play a pivotal role in
the  achievement  of  good  governance  and  improved  public  sector  performance  in  PNG,  and
thereby  will  promote  the  broad-based  economic  growth  and  social  development  that  are
essential if poverty is to be reduced. The PSP will build a performance orientation in the public
service  that  emphasizes  service  delivery,  transparency,  and  accountability.  It  will  ensure  the
supportive  strengthening  of  personnel  management  systems  and  processes;  and  it  will
strengthen  the  key  governance  agencies  (the  Auditor  General's  Office  and  Ombudsman
Commission). The PSP will make delivery of major services at national and subnational levels
more  predictable  and  effective.  Service  improvement  plans  for  health,  education,  agriculture,
and  transport  infrastructure  will  be  formulated  and  implemented  in  four  rural  provinces—one
from each of PNG’s four regions. This improvement in public service delivery to rural areas is
the major means by which PSP will alleviate PNG’s serious poverty problem.

institutional  change  in  the  public  service  because  these  are  difficult  to  express  quantitatively.
Instead,  analysis  must  be  largely  qualitative  and  supplemented  where  possible  by  selective
quantification. ADB’s Poverty Impact Assessment matrix is used as a means of organizing and

1.

Without the PSP

13. 
 The PNG Government acknowledges the validity of the public perception that the core
functions of public sector management have not been fulfilled efficiently or effectively in the past

 53

Appendix 4, page 5

decade, and accepts that this government failure has adversely affected the rural poor most of
all.  Revenue  administration,  public  expenditure  management,  and  public  administration
deteriorated  in  the  1990s  as  corruption  and  political  patronage  undermined  the  professional
ethos  of  the  public  service.  As  shown  in  Table  A4.2,  while  there  is  widespread  dissatisfaction
with  public  service  delivery,  the  dissatisfaction  is  most  intense  in  the  poorest  rural  regions.
There  is  a  clear  and  positive  correlation  between  the  level  of  consumption  and  the  degree  of
satisfaction with access to health care, education, and transport facilities.

In  the  absence  of  the  PSP  and  associated  loan  funds,  the  provision  of  public  services
14. 
will remain inefficient and unresponsive to the needs of society, and the short- and medium-term
budget  constraint  on  public  expenditure  will  be  tighter  than  with  the  PSP.  The  general
improvement  in  the  governance  environment  that  is  necessary  to  stimulate  private  sector-led
economic  growth  will  not  occur;  and  there  will  be  no  improvement  in  service  delivery  to  rural
areas  through  either  increased  public  spending  and/or  an  effective  reallocation  of  public
spending.

As observed in ADB’s study of poverty in the Pacific, “public sector expenditure is one of
15. 
the keys to ensuring that the poor and underprivileged have equality of opportunity…to transport
infrastructure  that  provides  the  rural  population  with  access  to  markets,  health  services,  and
education;  to  water  and  sanitation;  to  communication  networks…;  to  power  that  provides  the
light necessary to study...”8 Without the PSP and a program loan, access to these services by
the rural poor will not improve. Indeed, with the population growing at over 3 percent per annum,
access is likely to deteriorate if public spending neither increases sufficiently nor becomes more
effectively targeted. Hence, in the poverty impact assessment matrix, the major negative impact
on the poor of the without-PSP scenario is reduced access to basic public services.

In  addition  to  the  major  negative  impact,  there  will  be  some  indirect  negative  effects
16. 
through  the  labor  market.  Without  public  service  and  governance  reforms,  there  will  be  no
improvement  in  the  enabling  environment  for  the  private  sector.  This  in  turn  will  limit  the
chances  of  accelerated  economic  growth  and  consequent  employment  creation.  Public
spending  will  be  relatively  constrained,  reducing  demand  for  labor  indirectly,  and  perhaps
directly if some public service downsizing is needed to maintain aggregate fiscal discipline.

17. 
The  current  administration  is  firmly  committed  to  maintaining  a  stable  macroeconomic
environment,  and  has  introduced  legislation  that  ensures  the  central  bank  is  independent  and
may conduct sound monetary and exchange rate policies. This commitment is not likely to be
diminished  without  the  PSP,  but  the  absence  of  a  program  loan  could  make  fulfillment  of  the
commitment  more  difficult.  In  particular,  the  economy  will  be  more  vulnerable  to  speculative
capital outflows that placed downward pressure on the currency, and thus upwards pressure on
the general price level. On the other hand, the constraint on public expenditure imposed by the
lack  of  a  program  loan  would  have  a  deflationary  effect.  The  net  effect  cannot  be  predicted,
given the inherent uncertainty surrounding currency speculation.

18. 
In regard to relative price movements, the absence of a program loan may, as noted in
the previous paragraph, increase the likelihood of a nominal depreciation of the currency. To the
extent that such a depreciation is not offset by inflation, and to the extent that the poor are net
producers  of  traded  goods  and  net  consumers  of  nontraded  goods,  there  may  be  a  positive
impact. However, this assumes there are no supply-side constraints, when in fact these seem to
be severe. In addition, within the nontraded goods sector, the absence of a program loan may

ensure improved public service delivery. In particular, there will be greater access to key public
services by the poor in four provinces as a result of higher and more focused public spending.
Hence,  in  the  PIA  matrix,  the  major  positive  impact  of  the  PSP  on  the  poor  will  be  increased
access to basic public services.

27.
In addition to the major positive impact, some indirect positive effects will occur through
the  labor  market.  With  public  service  and  governance  reforms,  private  sector  will  be  able  to
increase its activities. This in turn will increase the chances of accelerated economic growth and
consequent  employment  creation.  Public  spending  will  be  higher  than  without  the  PSP,
increasing demand for labor indirectly. The increased demand is likely to benefit those in formal
employment primarily, but also may generate employment for those in the informal sector.

28. 
The  loan  will  support  the  Government's  efforts  to  maintain  a  stable  macroeconomic
environment  while  implementing  the  Structural  Reform  Program.  It  will  cover  short-  and
medium-term  adjustment  costs  during  2001-2003.  It  will  augment  foreign  reserves  and  thus
alleviate  speculative  pressure  on  the  currency  that  could  lead  to  depreciation  and  thus  higher
prices.  However,  the  easing  of  the  constraint  on  public  expenditure  will  increase  aggregate

the availability of public goods and services under with the PSP.

The  impact  on  transfers  through  direct  government  programs  is  largely  covered  by  the
PIA  matrix  category  of  access  of  the  poor  to  nonmarketed  public  goods  and  services.  In

In summary, with the PSP will have a significant positive impact on the poor because of

D.

Monitoring PSP Implementation and Evaluating Outcomes

32.
The  CACC  will  retain  the  responsibility  for  overall  coordination  of  the  PSP,  while  the
Public  Sector  Reform  Management  Unit  established  by  the  National  Executive  Council  will  be
responsible for coordination on a daily basis. General monitoring of PSP implementation will be
undertaken by ADB in partnership with the Government on a regular basis. For assessing the
PSP’s  impact  on  poverty,  key  performance  indicators  will  be  the  share  of  public  expenditure
allocated  to  basic  service  provision  in  rural  areas,  and  the  extent  of  client  satisfaction  with
provincial service delivery as revealed in surveys. Results of the latter are to be documented in
the reports of line ministries to CACC. Ultimately, progress in reducing poverty will have to be
evaluated through regular poverty analyses based on comparable household survey data.
